Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What does it mean for a country
to have a healthy economy? What does a healthy economy 
even look like? Does it look like this? What about like this? Economist Kate Raworth shared a
pretty interesting answer to this question on the TED Interview podcast. And it challenges an idea that most
economists take for granted. We live— particularly in the West, 
particularly in the last 150 years— in a society that has a very strong belief
that growth is the sign of progress. And to a certain extent, it’s true. We love to see our kids grow. We love to see nature growing in spring. Growth is a wonderful,
healthy phase of life. But in our economies, it’s like we’ve
turned to Peter Pan economics— the economy that never wanted to grow up. It wanted to grow and grow and grow
forever. And it becomes this permanent phase. But we already know, in our own bodies,
in our own lives, that there’s another side to this metaphor
of growth that we love so much. If I told you, my friend
had gone to the doctor, and the doctor told her she had a growth, that already feels completely different. Because in the space of our own bodies, we know that when something 
tries to grow endlessly within this healthy, dynamic living whole, it is a threat to the health of the whole, and we do everything we can to stop it. But when we step into our economies,
for some reason, we think that endless growth is progress. And we are now running
into severe problems because we are addicted to endless growth. Simon Kuznets, he was asked in the 1930s
by US Congress to come up, for the first time, with a single number 
to measure the output of the economy. America could say we produced so many tons
of steel and so many bags of grain— but can we add it all together? So they commissioned him 
to do this and he said, “Yes, I can. I can add it all together
in one number.” National income, what we now know as GDP—
but he gave it with a caveat. He said the welfare of a nation can
scarcely be known from this number, don’t mix it up with welfare, right? Because it tells us nothing about 
the unpaid caring work of parents, tells us nothing about the value
that’s created in communities, because that’s not priced, and it’s a measure of the flow 
of economic value. It tells us nothing about the
living world, the forests, the mines that get run down in order
to create this value. But the convenience, the temptation,
of this single number was so great that politicians sort of tucked it 
in their armpit and carried right on. And we ended up in a horse race
of pursuing GDP growth. The dream is that GDP can
keep on increasing, we can have increasing financial returns, but that we can decouple
from using Earth’s resources. We can use less carbon and less metals,
and minerals and plastics, and we can use less 
of the Earth’s land surface, and separate these two: 
ever rising GDP and falling resource use. It’s a fabulous dream; 
would that it would be true. We are at a time of climate emergency,
of ecosystem collapse. We need to radically reduce 
our use of Earth’s resources, and we're nowhere close to that. So I offer it as a compass for 21st
century prosperity. And this compass, silly though it sounds, it looks like a doughnut 
with the hole in the middle. So imagine from the center of it,
humanity’s use of Earth’s resources radiating out from the middle
of that picture. So in the hole, 
in the middle of the doughnut, that is the place where people 
don’t have enough resources to meet the essentials of life. It’s where people don’t have enough
food or health care, or education or housing or gender equality
or political voice or access to energy. And we want to leave nobody in that hole. We want to get everybody over a social
foundation of well-being, so all people on this planet can
lead lives of dignity and opportunity and community. And in low income countries, 
it absolutely makes sense, yes, let’s see the economy grow in ways 
that invest in health and education and transport for all. That was a very 20th century project. We're in the 21st century. We have Earth system scientists
who started looking at the impact we were having on the climate,
and the loss of soils and acid rain, and the hole in the ozone layer,
and the collapse of species. And they said, hang on. We’ve been ignoring our planet. In the growing to meet human needs, 
we have ignored the fact that we are deeply dependent 
on this delicately balanced living planet. It’s the only one we know of out there. And when we use Earth’s resources 
in such a way that we begin to push ourselves beyond
the living capacities of this planet, we are literally undermining the life
supporting systems on which we depend. So, hang on, just as there’s 
an inner limit of resource use, and we call out poverty and deprivation, there’s an outer limit of humanity’s
resource use. That’s ecological degradation. And we are breaking down
this planet on which we depend. So there you get the doughnut,
you get the inside, which is leave nobody behind in the hole. But don’t overshoot the outer ring either. And so the shape of progress
is fundamentally changed. It’s no longer this ever rising line
exponential growth, that we hear about in the financial news 
all the time. It’s balance. To me, a source of real hope is 
that we deeply understand this at the level of our body. You go to the doctor, the doctor will say, have enough food, but not too much, 
enough water, oxygen, exercise, sleep, anything you like— 
have enough, but not too much. Our health lies in balance. And if we can take that metaphor 
from the human body to the planetary body, we give ourselves a cracking
chance of understanding the deep interdependence of our world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: For western economies in the last 150 years, _______ is the sign of healthy economy and progress
Options: A. Equality, B. Growth, C. Equilibrium, D. Welfare
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who created the concept of GDP (Gross Domestic Product) to measure the output of an economy? Options: A. Kate Raworth, B. Simon Kuznets, C. John Maynard Keynes, D. Adam Smith Correct Option: B
Question 2: What model, proposed by Kate Raworth, aims to balance human well-being with environmental sustainability? Options: A. The circular economy model, B. The doughnut model, C. The sustainable development model, D. The green economy model Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main limitation of using GDP as a measure of a nation's welfare? Options: A. It only measures the flow of economic value and does not account for unpaid caring work, community value, or environmental degradation., B. It only measures the output of an economy and does not account for income inequality., C. It only measures the growth rate of an economy and does not account for inflation., D. It only measures the size of an economy and does not account for population growth. Correct Option: A
Question 4: According to the doughnut model, what are the two main goals of achieving a balanced economy? Options: A. To ensure everyone has access to basic resources and to maximize economic growth., B. To ensure everyone has access to basic resources and to avoid overshooting the planet's ecological limits., C. To maximize economic growth and to minimize income inequality., D. To minimize income inequality and to avoid overshooting the planet's ecological limits. Correct Option: B
Question 5: How can the doughnut model be applied to low-income countries? Options: A. By prioritizing investments in health, education, and transportation., B. By prioritizing investments in infrastructure, industry, and technology., C. By prioritizing investments in agriculture, manufacturing, and services., D. By prioritizing investments in energy, water, and sanitation. Correct Option: A
Question 6: How can the concept of balance be applied to individual lives? Options: A. By recognizing that too much of a good thing can be detrimental to health and well-being., B. By prioritizing economic growth and material wealth., C. By minimizing social connections and community engagement., D. By ignoring environmental sustainability and ecological limits. Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the relationship between economic growth and environmental degradation? Options: A. Economic growth leads to environmental degradation., B. Environmental degradation leads to economic growth., C. Economic growth and environmental degradation are unrelated., D. Economic growth and environmental degradation are mutually beneficial. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the main contrast between the doughnut model and traditional economic growth models? Options: A. The doughnut model prioritizes economic growth, while traditional models prioritize sustainability., B. The doughnut model prioritizes balance and sustainability, while traditional models prioritize economic growth., C. The doughnut model prioritizes social welfare, while traditional models prioritize economic growth., D. The doughnut model prioritizes environmental protection, while traditional models prioritize economic growth. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What does the doughnut model combine to create a new understanding of economic progress? Options: A. The concepts of social foundation and ecological limits., B. The concepts of economic growth and environmental degradation., C. The concepts of human well-being and material wealth., D. The concepts of sustainability and community engagement. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is synthesized with the concept of human well-being in the doughnut model? Options: A. The idea of balance and the concept of ecological limits., B. The idea of economic growth and the concept of material wealth., C. The idea of social connections and the concept of community engagement., D. The idea of environmental sustainability and the concept of ecological limits. Correct Option: A
Question 11: What is the main critique of traditional economic growth models presented by Kate Raworth? Options: A. They prioritize economic growth over sustainability and human well-being., B. They prioritize sustainability and human well-being over economic growth., C. They prioritize social welfare and community engagement over economic growth., D. They prioritize environmental protection and ecological limits over economic growth. Correct Option: A
Question 12: What is the justification for the doughnut model presented by Kate Raworth? Options: A. It prioritizes economic growth and material wealth., B. It prioritizes balance and sustainability., C. It prioritizes social connections and community engagement., D. It prioritizes environmental protection and ecological limits. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not a direct match, but Question 11 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the sign of a healthy economy and progress in Western economies, and the correct answer is "Growth". Question 11 critiques traditional economic growth models, stating that they prioritize economic growth over sustainability and human well-being, which aligns with the idea that growth is the sign of progress in Western economies.

Although the question wording and options are not identical, Question 11 is the most similar generated MCQ in terms of conveying the same idea and intent as the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 11

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What does it mean for a country
to have a healthy economy? What does a healthy economy 
even look like? Does it look like this? What about like this? Economist Kate Raworth shared a
pretty interesting answer to this question on the TED Interview podcast. And it challenges an idea that most
economists take for granted. We live— particularly in the West, 
particularly in the last 150 years— in a society that has a very strong belief
that growth is the sign of progress. And to a certain extent, it’s true. We love to see our kids grow. We love to see nature growing in spring. Growth is a wonderful,
healthy phase of life. But in our economies, it’s like we’ve

forever. And it becomes this permanent phase. But we already know, in our own bodies,
in our own lives, that there’s another side to this metaphor
of growth that we love so much. If I told you, my friend
had gone to the doctor, and the doctor told her she had a growth, that already feels completely different. Because in the space of our own bodies, we know that when something 
tries to grow endlessly within this healthy, dynamic living whole, it is a threat to the health of the whole, and we do everything we can to stop it. But when we step into our economies,

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Some economists hoped it was possible to decouple GDP from ______
Options: A. Supply and demand, B. Happiness index, C. Use of earth's resources, D. All of the above
Correct Option: C

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 7: What is the relationship between economic growth and environmental degradation?**

Options: A. Economic growth leads to environmental degradation., B. Environmental degradation leads to economic growth., C. Economic growth and environmental degradation are unrelated., D. Economic growth and environmental degradation are mutually beneficial.

Correct Option: A

However, this question does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that explicitly mentions the concept of decoupling GDP from the use of earth's resources.

A more suitable match is not present among the provided generated MCQs. However, if I had to choose the closest match based on the content, I would choose:

**Question 3: What is the main limitation of using GDP as a measure of a nation's welfare?**

This question does not directly address the concept of decoupling, but it does discuss the limitations of GDP, which is related to the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to provide an index, I would say that the closest match is:

**Index: 3**

However, please note that this is not a perfect match, and a more suitable generated MCQ would be one that explicitly addresses the concept of decoupling GDP from the use of earth's resources.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What does it mean for a country
to have a healthy economy? What does a healthy economy 
even look like? Does it look like this? What about like this? Economist Kate Raworth shared a
pretty interesting answer to this question on the TED Interview podcast. And it challenges an idea that most
economists take for granted. We live— particularly in the West, 
particularly in the last 150 years— in a society that has a very strong belief
that growth is the sign of progress. And to a certain extent, it’s true. We love to see our kids grow. We love to see nature growing in spring. Growth is a wonderful,
healthy phase of life. But in our economies, it’s like we’ve
turned to Peter Pan economics— the economy that never wanted to grow up. It wanted to grow and grow and grow
forever. And it becomes this permanent phase. But we already know, in our own bodies,
in our own lives, that there’s another side to this metaphor
of growth that we love so much. If I told you, my friend
had gone to the doctor, and the doctor told her she had a growth, that already feels completely different. Because in the space of our own bodies, we know that when something 
tries to grow endlessly within this healthy, dynamic living whole, it is a threat to the health of the whole, and we do everything we can to stop it. But when we step into our economies,

all the time. It’s balance. To me, a source of real hope is 
that we deeply understand this at the level of our body. You go to the doctor, the doctor will say, have enough food, but not too much,

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The hole in the middle doughnut economics represents
Options: A. the depletion of earth's resources, B. maximum growth of GDP, C. Extreme inequality, D. Where people don't have enough resources to meet their basic needs
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:

The idea of environmental sustainability and the concept of ecological limits. Correct Option: A

They prioritize sustainability and human well-being over economic growth., C. They prioritize social welfare and community engagement over economic growth., D. They prioritize environmental protection and ecological limits over economic growth. Correct Option: A
Question 12: What is the justification for the doughnut model presented by Kate Raworth? Options: A. It prioritizes economic growth and material wealth., B. It prioritizes balance and sustainability., C. It prioritizes social connections and community engagement., D. It prioritizes environmental protection and ecological limits. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

To ensure everyone has access to basic resources and to maximize economic growth., B. To ensure everyone has access to basic resources and to avoid overshooting the planet's ecological limits., C. To maximize economic growth and to minimize income inequality., D. To minimize income inequality and to avoid overshooting the planet's ecological limits. Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What does it mean for a country
to have a healthy economy? What does a healthy economy 
even look like? Does it look like this? What about like this? Economist Kate Raworth shared a
pretty interesting answer to this question on the TED Interview podcast. And it challenges an idea that most
economists take for granted. We live— particularly in the West, 
particularly in the last 150 years— in a society that has a very strong belief
that growth is the sign of progress. And to a certain extent, it’s true. We love to see our kids grow. We love to see nature growing in spring. Growth is a wonderful,
healthy phase of life. But in our economies, it’s like we’ve
turned to Peter Pan economics— the economy that never wanted to grow up. It wanted to grow and grow and grow
forever. And it becomes this permanent phase. But we already know, in our own bodies,
in our own lives, that there’s another side to this metaphor
of growth that we love so much. If I told you, my friend
had gone to the doctor, and the doctor told her she had a growth, that already feels completely different. Because in the space of our own bodies, we know that when something 
tries to grow endlessly within this healthy, dynamic living whole, it is a threat to the health of the whole, and we do everything we can to stop it. But when we step into our economies,
for some reason, we think that endless growth is progress. And we are now running
into severe problems because we are addicted to endless growth. Simon Kuznets, he was asked in the 1930s
by US Congress to come up, for the first time, with a single number 
to measure the output of the economy. America could say we produced so many tons
of steel and so many bags of grain— but can we add it all together? So they commissioned him 
to do this and he said, “Yes, I can. I can add it all together
in one number.” National income, what we now know as GDP—
but he gave it with a caveat. He said the welfare of a nation can
scarcely be known from this number, don’t mix it up with welfare, right? Because it tells us nothing about 
the unpaid caring work of parents, tells us nothing about the value
that’s created in communities, because that’s not priced, and it’s a measure of the flow 
of economic value. It tells us nothing about the
living world, the forests, the mines that get run down in order
to create this value. But the convenience, the temptation,
of this single number was so great that politicians sort of tucked it 
in their armpit and carried right on. And we ended up in a horse race
of pursuing GDP growth. The dream is that GDP can
keep on increasing, we can have increasing financial returns, but that we can decouple
from using Earth’s resources. We can use less carbon and less metals,
and minerals and plastics, and we can use less 
of the Earth’s land surface, and separate these two: 
ever rising GDP and falling resource use. It’s a fabulous dream; 
would that it would be true. We are at a time of climate emergency,
of ecosystem collapse. We need to radically reduce 
our use of Earth’s resources, and we're nowhere close to that. So I offer it as a compass for 21st
century prosperity. And this compass, silly though it sounds, it looks like a doughnut 
with the hole in the middle. So imagine from the center of it,
humanity’s use of Earth’s resources radiating out from the middle
of that picture. So in the hole, 
in the middle of the doughnut, that is the place where people 
don’t have enough resources to meet the essentials of life. It’s where people don’t have enough
food or health care, or education or housing or gender equality
or political voice or access to energy. And we want to leave nobody in that hole. We want to get everybody over a social
foundation of well-being, so all people on this planet can
lead lives of dignity and opportunity and community. And in low income countries, 
it absolutely makes sense, yes, let’s see the economy grow in ways 
that invest in health and education and transport for all. That was a very 20th century project. We're in the 21st century. We have Earth system scientists
who started looking at the impact we were having on the climate,
and the loss of soils and acid rain, and the hole in the ozone layer,
and the collapse of species. And they said, hang on. We’ve been ignoring our planet. In the growing to meet human needs, 
we have ignored the fact that we are deeply dependent 
on this delicately balanced living planet. It’s the only one we know of out there. And when we use Earth’s resources 
in such a way that we begin to push ourselves beyond
the living capacities of this planet, we are literally undermining the life
supporting systems on which we depend. So, hang on, just as there’s 
an inner limit of resource use, and we call out poverty and deprivation, there’s an outer limit of humanity’s
resource use. That’s ecological degradation. And we are breaking down
this planet on which we depend. So there you get the doughnut,
you get the inside, which is leave nobody behind in the hole. But don’t overshoot the outer ring either. And so the shape of progress
is fundamentally changed. It’s no longer this ever rising line
exponential growth, that we hear about in the financial news 
all the time. It’s balance. To me, a source of real hope is 
that we deeply understand this at the level of our body. You go to the doctor, the doctor will say, have enough food, but not too much, 
enough water, oxygen, exercise, sleep, anything you like— 
have enough, but not too much. Our health lies in balance. And if we can take that metaphor 
from the human body to the planetary body, we give ourselves a cracking
chance of understanding the deep interdependence of our world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Beyond the outer rim of the donut represents
Options: A. Ecological destruction, B. Sustainable living, C. Global GDP growth target, D. Regeneration
Correct Option: A

It only measures the flow of economic value and does not account for unpaid caring work, community value, or environmental degradation., B. It only measures the output of an economy and does not account for income inequality., C. It only measures the growth rate of an economy and does not account for inflation., D. It only measures the size of an economy and does not account for population growth. Correct Option: A

To ensure everyone has access to basic resources and to maximize economic growth., B. To ensure everyone has access to basic resources and to avoid overshooting the planet's ecological limits., C. By prioritizing investments in infrastructure, industry, and technology., C. By prioritizing investments in agriculture, manufacturing, and services., D. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The year is 1656. Your body is wracked 
by violent chills. Your head pounds,
your muscles are too weak to sit up, and you feel like rancid, hard-boiled eggs are squeezing out of your neck 
and armpits. In your feverish state, you see 
a strange-looking man approach, his face obscured by a beak-like mask,
his body covered from head to toe. He examines you 
and even without seeing his face, you know the diagnosis: you have the plague. The plague stands out as one of the most 
terrifying and destructive diseases in human history. It swept across large parts of Afro-
Eurasia in three separate pandemics starting in the 6th, 14th,
and 19th centuries; killed tens of millions of people, and had— in the best of cases— 
about a 40% survival rate. The European plague doctor, with his
beaked mask and wizard-like robes, is one of the images most popularly
associated with plague today. He’s often found in books and films 
about the 14th century pandemic known as the Black Death. The only problem is
that’s about as accurate as placing a modern surgeon at the court
of Louis the 14th in Versailles. The confusion is understandable though— the Black Death had several aftershocks, including a series of devastating
outbreaks in Western Europe during the 17th century. This is when the iconic plague doctor
actually emerged on the scene. First described in the early 17th century, the outfit consisted of a hood 
with crystal eyepieces and a beak filled with a pungent 
combination of herbs and compounds. This could include cinnamon, pepper,
turpentine, roast copper, and powdered viper flesh. This recipe was inspired by the famed
2nd century Greco-Roman physician Galen, and was thought to ward off poisoned air
known as miasma. People believed this bad air
spread plague after emanating from swamps and sources of decay, such as dead plants or animal carcasses. In earlier centuries, doctors across
Europe carried metal pomanders filled with similar mixtures, and it’s possible that the beak evolved
as a hands-free alternative. The rest of the costume, which included 
an oiled leather robe, boots and gloves, acted as kind of an early hazmat suit, likely designed to block miasma 
from entering through the skin’s pores. While this shows some basic understanding
that plague spread from one place to another, these doctors couldn’t know that,
in most cases, the true culprit was a tiny flea 
transmitting the bacteria, Yersinia pestis, 
from one person or animal to another. It’s possible that the plague doctor’s
outfit may have provided some unintentional protection 
from flea bites. However, not enough information
survives to know whether the costumed doctors fared any better than
their ordinarily robed counterparts. It's no surprise that this bizarre getup
has captured popular imagination, despite the fact that its use was limited
to a few places in Italy and France during the 17th and early 18th centuries. Even at the time, it was viewed
with macabre fascination and occasionally used to mock
the ineffective and corrupt practices of some physicians. Until the 20th century, there was 
no effective treatment for the plague, but that didn’t stop doctors— 
costumed or not— from trying. They consulted the works of earlier
physicians for guidance, did what they could to fend off miasma, and prescribed a variety 
of concoctions and antidotes. They also relied on pre-modern
medical mainstays. These could include bloodletting, which involved draining (sometimes 
concerningly large amounts of) blood in an attempt to remove poison 
or restore the body’s natural balance. Or cupping, where the rim 
of a heated glass was placed over swollen lymph nodes 
in hopes of making them burst sooner— a sign, when it occurred naturally,
that a plague patient was on the mend. Or— perhaps most painfully—
cautery, which involved lancing the lymph nodes
with a red-hot poker to release the blackened pus within. A lot has changed since their times. Modern medicine has given us the means
to quickly identify bacterial as well as viral threats and to effectively mobilize against them. We also have access to technologies
like test kits, masks to deter the spread 
of respiratory viruses, and vaccines; and we conduct robust trials to make
sure they’re safe and effective. But some things don’t change: we still depend on the courage
and compassion of medical professionals who voluntarily risk their lives against an invisible attacker to help
and comfort those who need it most.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many plague pandemics have there been in human history?
Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In which centuries did the plague sweep across Afro-Eurasia in three separate pandemics? Options: A. 5th, 12th, and 18th centuries, B. 6th, 14th, and 19th centuries, C. 7th, 15th, and 20th centuries, D. 8th, 16th, and 21st centuries Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the estimated survival rate of the plague in the best of cases? Options: A. 20%, B. 30%, C. 40%, D. 50% Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the primary purpose of the European plague doctor's outfit? Options: A. To ward off poisoned air or miasma, B. To protect against flea bites, C. To treat the plague with herbal remedies, D. To perform surgical procedures Correct Option: A
Question 4: How did modern medicine change the way people respond to diseases like the plague? Options: A. It led to a greater reliance on pre-modern medical mainstays, B. It provided the means to quickly identify and mobilize against bacterial and viral threats, C. It resulted in a decrease in the importance of medical professionals, D. It had no significant impact on disease response Correct Option: B
Question 5: What aspect of the concept of miasma remains relevant to modern-day understandings of disease transmission and prevention? Options: A. The use of herbs and compounds to ward off disease, B. The recognition of environmental factors contributing to disease transmission, C. The denial of microorganisms' role in disease transmission, D. The reliance on pre-modern medical mainstays Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is an example of how modern medicine can be applied to real-world scenarios of disease outbreaks and pandemics? Options: A. Using test kits, masks, and vaccines to prevent the spread of disease, B. Relying solely on pre-modern medical mainstays, C. Ignoring the role of microorganisms in disease transmission, D. Using herbal remedies to treat diseases Correct Option: A
Question 7: What potential benefit of the plague doctor's outfit could inform modern strategies for disease prevention? Options: A. The use of herbal remedies to treat diseases, B. The reliance on pre-modern medical mainstays, C. The incorporation of protective clothing and gear to prevent the spread of diseases, D. The denial of microorganisms' role in disease transmission Correct Option: C
Question 8: What can be inferred about the relationship between the plague and the development of modern medicine? Options: A. The plague had no significant impact on the development of modern medicine, B. The plague led to a greater reliance on pre-modern medical mainstays, C. The plague drove the development of modern medicine by highlighting the need for new approaches to disease transmission and prevention, D. The plague resulted in a decrease in the importance of medical professionals Correct Option: C
Question 9: How effective were pre-modern medical mainstays like bloodletting, cupping, and cautery in treating diseases? Options: A. Very effective, B. Somewhat effective, C. Not very effective, D. Not effective, and often caused more harm than good Correct Option: D
Question 10: What can be said about the ethics of using unproven medical treatments and practices? Options: A. They are always justified in emergency situations, B. They are never justified and should be avoided at all costs, C. They should be evaluated on a case-by-case basis and used with caution, D. They are always more effective than proven medical treatments and practices Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although Question 1 does not directly ask about the number of plague pandemics, it does mention "three separate pandemics" in the question stem, which aligns with the correct option (C) of the ground truth MCQ. The centuries mentioned in Question 1 also correspond to the information provided in the transcript about the plague pandemics.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The year is 1656. Your body is wracked 
by violent chills. Your head pounds,
your muscles are too weak to sit up, and you feel like rancid, hard-boiled eggs are squeezing out of your neck 
and armpits. In your feverish state, you see 
a strange-looking man approach, his face obscured by a beak-like mask,
his body covered from head to toe. He examines you 
and even without seeing his face, you know the diagnosis: you have the plague. The plague stands out as one of the most 
terrifying and destructive diseases in human history. It swept across large parts of Afro-
Eurasia in three separate pandemics starting in the 6th, 14th,
and 19th centuries; killed tens of millions of people, and had— in the best of cases— 
about a 40% survival rate. The European plague doctor, with his
beaked mask and wizard-like robes, is one of the images most popularly
associated with plague today. He’s often found in books and films 
about the 14th century pandemic known as the Black Death. The only problem is
that’s about as accurate as placing a modern surgeon at the court
of Louis the 14th in Versailles. The confusion is understandable though— the Black Death had several aftershocks, including a series of devastating
outbreaks in Western Europe during the 17th century. This is when the iconic plague doctor
actually emerged on the scene. First described in the early 17th century, the outfit consisted of a hood 
with crystal eyepieces and a beak filled with a pungent 
combination of herbs and compounds. This could include cinnamon, pepper,
turpentine, roast copper, and powdered viper flesh. This recipe was inspired by the famed
2nd century Greco-Roman physician Galen, and was thought to ward off poisoned air
known as miasma. People believed this bad air
spread plague after emanating from swamps and sources of decay, such as dead plants or animal carcasses. In earlier centuries, doctors across
Europe carried metal pomanders filled with similar mixtures, and it’s possible that the beak evolved
as a hands-free alternative. The rest of the costume, which included 
an oiled leather robe, boots and gloves, acted as kind of an early hazmat suit, likely designed to block miasma 
from entering through the skin’s pores. While this shows some basic understanding
that plague spread from one place to another, these doctors couldn’t know that,
in most cases, the true culprit was a tiny flea 
transmitting the bacteria, Yersinia pestis, 
from one person or animal to another. It’s possible that the plague doctor’s
outfit may have provided some unintentional protection 
from flea bites. However, not enough information
survives to know whether the costumed doctors fared any better than
their ordinarily robed counterparts. It's no surprise that this bizarre getup
has captured popular imagination, despite the fact that its use was limited
to a few places in Italy and France during the 17th and early 18th centuries. Even at the time, it was viewed
with macabre fascination and occasionally used to mock
the ineffective and corrupt practices of some physicians. Until the 20th century, there was 
no effective treatment for the plague, but that didn’t stop doctors— 
costumed or not— from trying. They consulted the works of earlier
physicians for guidance, did what they could to fend off miasma, and prescribed a variety 
of concoctions and antidotes. They also relied on pre-modern
medical mainstays. These could include bloodletting, which involved draining (sometimes 
concerningly large amounts of) blood in an attempt to remove poison 
or restore the body’s natural balance. Or cupping, where the rim 
of a heated glass was placed over swollen lymph nodes 
in hopes of making them burst sooner— a sign, when it occurred naturally,
that a plague patient was on the mend. Or— perhaps most painfully—
cautery, which involved lancing the lymph nodes
with a red-hot poker to release the blackened pus within. A lot has changed since their times. Modern medicine has given us the means
to quickly identify bacterial as well as viral threats and to effectively mobilize against them. We also have access to technologies
like test kits, masks to deter the spread 
of respiratory viruses, and vaccines; and we conduct robust trials to make
sure they’re safe and effective. But some things don’t change: we still depend on the courage
and compassion of medical professionals who voluntarily risk their lives against an invisible attacker to help
and comfort those who need it most.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Without antibiotics, what is the best chance a person had of surviving the plague?
Options: A. 40%, B. 50%, C. 75%, D. 90%
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In which centuries did the plague sweep across Afro-Eurasia in three separate pandemics? Options: A. 5th, 12th, and 18th centuries, B. 6th, 14th, and 19th centuries, C. 7th, 15th, and 20th centuries, D. 8th, 16th, and 21st centuries Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the estimated survival rate of the plague in the best of cases? Options: A. 20%, B. 30%, C. 40%, D. 50% Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the primary purpose of the European plague doctor's outfit? Options: A. To ward off poisoned air or miasma, B. To protect against flea bites, C. To treat the plague with herbal remedies, D. To perform surgical procedures Correct Option: A
Question 4: How did modern medicine change the way people respond to diseases like the plague? Options: A. It led to a greater reliance on pre-modern medical mainstays, B. It provided the means to quickly identify and mobilize against bacterial and viral threats, C. It resulted in a decrease in the importance of medical professionals, D. It had no significant impact on disease response Correct Option: B
Question 5: What aspect of the concept of miasma remains relevant to modern-day understandings of disease transmission and prevention? Options: A. The use of herbs and compounds to ward off disease, B. The recognition of environmental factors contributing to disease transmission, C. The denial of microorganisms' role in disease transmission, D. The reliance on pre-modern medical mainstays Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is an example of how modern medicine can be applied to real-world scenarios of disease outbreaks and pandemics? Options: A. Using test kits, masks, and vaccines to prevent the spread of disease, B. Relying solely on pre-modern medical mainstays, C. Ignoring the role of microorganisms in disease transmission, D. Using herbal remedies to treat diseases Correct Option: A
Question 7: What potential benefit of the plague doctor's outfit could inform modern strategies for disease prevention? Options: A. The use of herbal remedies to treat diseases, B. The reliance on pre-modern medical mainstays, C. The incorporation of protective clothing and gear to prevent the spread of diseases, D. The denial of microorganisms' role in disease transmission Correct Option: C
Question 8: What can be inferred about the relationship between the plague and the development of modern medicine? Options: A. The plague had no significant impact on the development of modern medicine, B. The plague led to a greater reliance on pre-modern medical mainstays, C. The plague drove the development of modern medicine by highlighting the need for new approaches to disease transmission and prevention, D. The plague resulted in a decrease in the importance of medical professionals Correct Option: C
Question 9: How effective were pre-modern medical mainstays like bloodletting, cupping, and cautery in treating diseases? Options: A. Very effective, B. Somewhat effective, C. Not very effective, D. Not effective, and often caused more harm than good Correct Option: D
Question 10: What can be said about the ethics of using unproven medical treatments and practices? Options: A. They are always justified in emergency situations, B. They are never justified and should be avoided at all costs, C. They should be evaluated on a case-by-case basis and used with caution, D. They are always more effective than proven medical treatments and practices Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: What was the estimated survival rate of the plague in the best of cases? 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (survival rate of the plague), options (percentage-based answers), and content (estimated survival rate in the best of cases).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The year is 1656. Your body is wracked 
by violent chills. Your head pounds,
your muscles are too weak to sit up, and you feel like rancid, hard-boiled eggs are squeezing out of your neck 
and armpits. In your feverish state, you see 
a strange-looking man approach, his face obscured by a beak-like mask,
his body covered from head to toe. He examines you 
and even without seeing his face, you know the diagnosis: you have the plague. The plague stands out as one of the most 
terrifying and destructive diseases in human history. It swept across large parts of Afro-
Eurasia in three separate pandemics starting in the 6th, 14th,
and 19th centuries; killed tens of millions of people, and had— in the best of cases— 
about a 40% survival rate. The European plague doctor, with his
beaked mask and wizard-like robes, is one of the images most popularly
associated with plague today. He’s often found in books and films 
about the 14th century pandemic known as the Black Death. The only problem is
that’s about as accurate as placing a modern surgeon at the court
of Louis the 14th in Versailles. The confusion is understandable though— the Black Death had several aftershocks, including a series of devastating
outbreaks in Western Europe during the 17th century. This is when the iconic plague doctor
actually emerged on the scene. First described in the early 17th century, the outfit consisted of a hood 
with crystal eyepieces and a beak filled with a pungent 
combination of herbs and compounds. This could include cinnamon, pepper,
turpentine, roast copper, and powdered viper flesh. This recipe was inspired by the famed
2nd century Greco-Roman physician Galen, and was thought to ward off poisoned air
known as miasma. People believed this bad air
spread plague after emanating from swamps and sources of decay, such as dead plants or animal carcasses. In earlier centuries, doctors across
Europe carried metal pomanders filled with similar mixtures, and it’s possible that the beak evolved
as a hands-free alternative. The rest of the costume, which included 
an oiled leather robe, boots and gloves, acted as kind of an early hazmat suit, likely designed to block miasma 
from entering through the skin’s pores. While this shows some basic understanding
that plague spread from one place to another, these doctors couldn’t know that,
in most cases, the true culprit was a tiny flea 
transmitting the bacteria, Yersinia pestis, 
from one person or animal to another. It’s possible that the plague doctor’s
outfit may have provided some unintentional protection 
from flea bites. However, not enough information
survives to know whether the costumed doctors fared any better than
their ordinarily robed counterparts. It's no surprise that this bizarre getup
has captured popular imagination, despite the fact that its use was limited
to a few places in Italy and France during the 17th and early 18th centuries. Even at the time, it was viewed
with macabre fascination and occasionally used to mock
the ineffective and corrupt practices of some physicians. Until the 20th century, there was 
no effective treatment for the plague, but that didn’t stop doctors— 
costumed or not— from trying. They consulted the works of earlier
physicians for guidance, did what they could to fend off miasma, and prescribed a variety 
of concoctions and antidotes. They also relied on pre-modern
medical mainstays. These could include bloodletting, which involved draining (sometimes 
concerningly large amounts of) blood in an attempt to remove poison 
or restore the body’s natural balance. Or cupping, where the rim 
of a heated glass was placed over swollen lymph nodes 
in hopes of making them burst sooner— a sign, when it occurred naturally,
that a plague patient was on the mend. Or— perhaps most painfully—
cautery, which involved lancing the lymph nodes
with a red-hot poker to release the blackened pus within. A lot has changed since their times. Modern medicine has given us the means
to quickly identify bacterial as well as viral threats and to effectively mobilize against them. We also have access to technologies
like test kits, masks to deter the spread 
of respiratory viruses, and vaccines; and we conduct robust trials to make
sure they’re safe and effective. But some things don’t change: we still depend on the courage
and compassion of medical professionals who voluntarily risk their lives against an invisible attacker to help
and comfort those who need it most.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following was NOT listed as one of the ingredients put inside plague masks?
Options: A. Cinnamon, B. Arsenic, C. Turpentine, D. Powdered viper flesh
Correct Option: B

The year is 1656. Your body is wracked 
by violent chills. Your head pounds,
your muscles are too weak to sit up, and you feel like rancid, hard-boiled eggs are squeezing out of your neck 
and armpits. In your feverish state, you see

and 19th centuries; killed tens of millions of people, and had— in the best of cases— 
about a 40% survival rate. The European plague doctor, with his

associated with plague today. He’s often found in books and films 
about the 14th century pandemic known as the Black Death. The only problem is
that’s about as accurate as placing a modern surgeon at the court
of Louis the 14th in Versailles. The confusion is understandable though— the Black Death had several aftershocks, including a series of devastating

actually emerged on the scene. First described in the early 17th century, the outfit consisted of a hood

combination of herbs and compounds. This could include cinnamon, pepper,

known as miasma. People believed this bad air
spread plague after emanating from swamps and sources of decay, such as dead plants or animal carcasses. In earlier centuries, doctors across

as a hands-free alternative. The rest of the costume, which included 
an oiled leather robe, boots and gloves, acted as kind of an early hazmat suit, likely designed to block miasma 
from entering through the skin’s pores. While this shows some basic understanding
that plague spread from one place to another, these doctors couldn’t know that,
in most cases, the true culprit was a tiny flea 
transmitting the bacteria, Yersinia pestis, 
from one person or animal to another. It’s possible that the plague doctor’s
outfit may have provided some unintentional protection 
from flea bites. However, not enough information
survives to know whether the costumed doctors fared any better than
their ordinarily robed counterparts. It's no surprise that this bizarre getup
has captured popular imagination, despite the fact that its use was limited
to a few places in Italy and France during the 17th and early 18th centuries. Even at the time, it was viewed
with macabre fascination and occasionally used to mock

that a plague patient was on the mend. Or— perhaps most painfully—

with a red-hot poker to release the blackened pus within. A lot has changed since their times. Modern medicine has given us the means
to quickly identify bacterial as well as viral threats and to effectively mobilize against them. We also have access to technologies
like test kits, masks to deter the spread 
of respiratory viruses, and vaccines; and we conduct robust trials to make

and comfort those who need it most.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
The year is 1656. Your body is wracked 
by violent chills. Your head pounds,
your muscles are too weak to sit up, and you feel like rancid, hard-boiled eggs are squeezing out of your neck 
and armpits. In your feverish state, you see 
a strange-looking man approach, his face obscured by a beak-like mask,
his body covered from head to toe. He examines you 
and even without seeing his face, you know the diagnosis: you have the plague. The plague stands out as one of the most 
terrifying and destructive diseases in human history. It swept across large parts of Afro-
Eurasia in three separate pandemics starting in the 6th, 14th,
and 19th centuries; killed tens of millions of people, and had— in the best of cases— 
about a 40% survival rate. The European plague doctor, with his
beaked mask and wizard-like robes, is one of the images most popularly
associated with plague today. He’s often found in books and films 
about the 14th century pandemic known as the Black Death. The only problem is
that’s about as accurate as placing a modern surgeon at the court
of Louis the 14th in Versailles. The confusion is understandable though— the Black Death had several aftershocks, including a series of devastating
outbreaks in Western Europe during the 17th century. This is when the iconic plague doctor
actually emerged on the scene. First described in the early 17th century, the outfit consisted of a hood 
with crystal eyepieces and a beak filled with a pungent 
combination of herbs and compounds. This could include cinnamon, pepper,
turpentine, roast copper, and powdered viper flesh. This recipe was inspired by the famed
2nd century Greco-Roman physician Galen, and was thought to ward off poisoned air
known as miasma. People believed this bad air
spread plague after emanating from swamps and sources of decay, such as dead plants or animal carcasses. In earlier centuries, doctors across
Europe carried metal pomanders filled with similar mixtures, and it’s possible that the beak evolved
as a hands-free alternative. The rest of the costume, which included 
an oiled leather robe, boots and gloves, acted as kind of an early hazmat suit, likely designed to block miasma 
from entering through the skin’s pores. While this shows some basic understanding
that plague spread from one place to another, these doctors couldn’t know that,
in most cases, the true culprit was a tiny flea 
transmitting the bacteria, Yersinia pestis, 
from one person or animal to another. It’s possible that the plague doctor’s
outfit may have provided some unintentional protection 
from flea bites. However, not enough information
survives to know whether the costumed doctors fared any better than
their ordinarily robed counterparts. It's no surprise that this bizarre getup
has captured popular imagination, despite the fact that its use was limited
to a few places in Italy and France during the 17th and early 18th centuries. Even at the time, it was viewed
with macabre fascination and occasionally used to mock
the ineffective and corrupt practices of some physicians. Until the 20th century, there was 
no effective treatment for the plague, but that didn’t stop doctors— 
costumed or not— from trying. They consulted the works of earlier
physicians for guidance, did what they could to fend off miasma, and prescribed a variety 
of concoctions and antidotes. They also relied on pre-modern
medical mainstays. These could include bloodletting, which involved draining (sometimes 
concerningly large amounts of) blood in an attempt to remove poison 
or restore the body’s natural balance. Or cupping, where the rim 
of a heated glass was placed over swollen lymph nodes 
in hopes of making them burst sooner— a sign, when it occurred naturally,
that a plague patient was on the mend. Or— perhaps most painfully—
cautery, which involved lancing the lymph nodes
with a red-hot poker to release the blackened pus within. A lot has changed since their times. Modern medicine has given us the means
to quickly identify bacterial as well as viral threats and to effectively mobilize against them. We also have access to technologies
like test kits, masks to deter the spread 
of respiratory viruses, and vaccines; and we conduct robust trials to make
sure they’re safe and effective. But some things don’t change: we still depend on the courage
and compassion of medical professionals who voluntarily risk their lives against an invisible attacker to help
and comfort those who need it most.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was the plague mask designed to protect people from?
Options: A. Miasma, B. Evil spirits, C. Sputum, D. Blood
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In which centuries did the plague sweep across Afro-Eurasia in three separate pandemics? Options: A. 5th, 12th, and 18th centuries, B. 6th, 14th, and 19th centuries, C. 7th, 15th, and 20th centuries, D. 8th, 16th, and 21st centuries Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the estimated survival rate of the plague in the best of cases? Options: A. 20%, B. 30%, C. 40%, D. 50% Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the primary purpose of the European plague doctor's outfit? Options: A. To ward off poisoned air or miasma, B. To protect against flea bites, C. To treat the plague with herbal remedies, D. To perform surgical procedures Correct Option: A
Question 4: How did modern medicine change the way people respond to diseases like the plague? Options: A. It led to a greater reliance on pre-modern medical mainstays, B. It provided the means to quickly identify and mobilize against bacterial and viral threats, C. It resulted in a decrease in the importance of medical professionals, D. It had no significant impact on disease response Correct Option: B
Question 5: What aspect of the concept of miasma remains relevant to modern-day understandings of disease transmission and prevention? Options: A. The use of herbs and compounds to ward off disease, B. The recognition of environmental factors contributing to disease transmission, C. The denial of microorganisms' role in disease transmission, D. The reliance on pre-modern medical mainstays Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is an example of how modern medicine can be applied to real-world scenarios of disease outbreaks and pandemics? Options: A. Using test kits, masks, and vaccines to prevent the spread of disease, B. Relying solely on pre-modern medical mainstays, C. Ignoring the role of microorganisms in disease transmission, D. Using herbal remedies to treat diseases Correct Option: A
Question 7: What potential benefit of the plague doctor's outfit could inform modern strategies for disease prevention? Options: A. The use of herbal remedies to treat diseases, B. The reliance on pre-modern medical mainstays, C. The incorporation of protective clothing and gear to prevent the spread of diseases, D. The denial of microorganisms' role in disease transmission Correct Option: C
Question 8: What can be inferred about the relationship between the plague and the development of modern medicine? Options: A. The plague had no significant impact on the development of modern medicine, B. The plague led to a greater reliance on pre-modern medical mainstays, C. The plague drove the development of modern medicine by highlighting the need for new approaches to disease transmission and prevention, D. The plague resulted in a decrease in the importance of medical professionals Correct Option: C

Question 10: What can be said about the ethics of using unproven medical treatments and practices? Options: A. They are always justified in emergency situations, B. They are never justified and should be avoided at all costs, C. They should be evaluated on a case-by-case basis and used with caution, D. They are always more effective than proven medical treatments and practices Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the years before World War Two, a pair of brothers worked together
as shoemakers in the German town of Herzogenaurach. But during the war, the siblings
had a terrible argument— a fight so explosive it split
the family business in two. At first, the feud only infected 
their newly competing personnel. But over the coming years, this disagreement divided
all of Herzogenaurach. Residents became fiercely
loyal to one brand of shoe. Local businesses chose sides and 
marriage across lines was discouraged. Herzogenaurach eventually became 
known as “the town of bent necks” because its residents looked down 
to ensure they were interacting with members of their group. But could such a serious divide
really be about shoes? Doesn’t it take more significant 
cultural differences to produce this degree of conflict? To answer this question, we can turn 
to social psychologist Henri Tajfel and his collaborators 
at the University of Bristol. This team developed 
the minimal group paradigm, a methodology designed to investigate the minimal conditions required 
to turn people against each other. Their plan was to gather participants 
without the usual factors that lead to hostility, such as religious, ethnic, 
gender, or other cultural differences. Then, they would split into groups, and run them through scenarios
that added one variable at a time to see what stirred up conflict. But first, they needed
a control condition— a pair of groups without any group bias. The researchers told participants
they were being grouped based on their ability to estimate things
correctly or incorrectly; but in reality, 
the groups were totally random. Since the researchers ensured none
of the participants interacted, no one could form any judgments
or personal bonds. Then everyone was given resources
to distribute. Each participant was free to give
resources to members of either group, and importantly, everything was anonymous. So whatever a participant decided, it had no impact on how many resources
they personally would receive. With all the ingredients 
for discrimination removed and no reason for competition
over resources, the scientists assumed this would
make a conflict-free baseline for further research. But even in these groups, where membership was only defined 
by a perceived similarity in possessing an arbitrary skill, individuals still showed in-group bias. They consistently gave more to members
of their own group than the out-group. Later, research went even further, informing participants that the only thing
determining their group membership was a coin flip. But group bias still occurred. The minimal groups of “us” and “them”
were enough. So, in the absence of stereotypes, 
resource conflicts and status differences, what was left? What could possibly account for people 
showing clear preferences for the most temporary and meaningless
of groups? The answer that came to Tajfel 
and his colleagues was social identity. People regularly use group membership 
to help determine their sense of identity. And these minimal group experiments
suggested that simply being categorized as part of a group is enough to link 
that group to a person’s sense of self. Then, in an effort to create
a meaningful identity, participants allocated more resources
to their in-group than the out-group— pursuing their group's interests despite
no clear benefit to themselves as individuals. Variants of these experiments have 
been conducted around the globe, examining how a shared sense 
of “us” can affect our attention, perception, memory, and emotions. The mental processes
behind minimal group distinctions appear to be the same as many of those
that underlie real group identities. So it is possible that these seemingly
insignificant differences can harden into much more serious divides. That said, minimal groups don't
always drive people apart. Bringing individuals together 
in a new group can temporarily help people
overcome entrenched biases. However, these positive effects are easily
negated by external factors that reinforce existing group identities. Ultimately, the psychology of groups
is part of the human condition, and our tendency towards in-group bias
is an undeniable part of that. So it's up to all of us to make
our groups and ourselves as inclusive of others as possible.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Social Psychologist Henri Tajfel and colleagues developed the minimal group paradigm to investigate:
Options: A. Why people tend to form small groups, B. The minimal conditions required for people to allocate resources based on group identity, C. The optimal conditions required for people to form racial stereotypes about others, D. The cultural conditions required for people of different religions to turn against each other
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What occupation did the two brothers in Herzogenaurach, Germany, share before World War Two? Options: A. Shoemakers, B. Businessmen, C. Researchers, D. Social psychologists Correct Option: A
Question 2: Who developed the minimal group paradigm to investigate the conditions required for conflict? Options: A. Henri Tajfel, B. Albert Bandura, C. Sigmund Freud, D. Jean Piaget Correct Option: A
Question 3: What does the story of the two brothers in Herzogenaurach illustrate about group conflict? Options: A. That it is always based on significant cultural differences, B. That it can be resolved through external interventions, C. That even minor disagreements can lead to deep divisions, D. That group conflict is only influenced by social identity Correct Option: C
Question 4: What does the minimal group paradigm demonstrate about the nature of group membership? Options: A. That it is based on cultural differences, B. That it is influenced by external factors, C. That even arbitrary group membership can lead to in-group bias, D. That group membership is shaped by social learning theory Correct Option: C
Question 5: How can the concept of minimal groups be applied in real-world scenarios to promote positive outcomes? Options: A. Creating divisions within teams or communities, B. Studying the impact of cultural differences on group behavior, C. Fostering competition among groups, D. Fostering inclusivity and cooperation in team-building exercises or community development programs Correct Option: D
Question 6: What can understanding the psychology of groups help individuals and organizations address? Options: A. Issues related to diversity, equity, and inclusion, B. Problems related to social learning theory, C. Conflicts arising from cultural differences, D. Challenges related to cognitive dissonance theory Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the key factor in shaping individuals' behavior and attitudes towards in-groups and out-groups? Options: A. Cultural differences, B. External factors, C. Social learning theory, D. The relationship between group membership and social identity Correct Option: D
Question 8: What does the minimal group paradigm highlight about the nature of group membership? Options: A. Its arbitrary nature and significant impact on behavior, B. Its basis in cultural differences, C. Its influence on social learning theory, D. Its effect on cognitive dissonance theory Correct Option: A
Question 9: What can combining the concepts of minimal groups and social identity provide insights into? Options: A. The complex dynamics of group behavior and conflict, B. The effects of cultural differences on group behavior, C. The role of social learning theory in shaping behavior, D. The impact of external factors on group cohesion Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can integrating the findings of the minimal group experiments with other theories of social psychology offer? Options: A. A more comprehensive understanding of human behavior, B. A deeper understanding of cognitive dissonance theory, C. A greater awareness of social learning theory, D. A more nuanced understanding of cultural differences Correct Option: A
Question 11: What aspects of the minimal group paradigm's methodology and findings can be evaluated? Options: A. Their validity, reliability, and generalizability to real-world contexts, B. Their impact on social learning theory, C. Their effect on cognitive dissonance theory, D. Their basis in cultural differences Correct Option: A
Question 12: What can be assessed and critiqued about the minimal group paradigm? Options: A. Its implications for our understanding of human behavior and social psychology, B. Its methodology and research design, C. Its influence on social learning theory, D. Its relevance to real-world contexts Correct Option: A
Question 13: What is the concept of "social identity" in the context of group membership? Options: A. A person's sense of self based on their group membership, B. A person's sense of self based on their cultural differences, C. A person's sense of self based on their social learning theory, D. A person's sense of self based on their cognitive dissonance theory Correct Option: A
Question 14: How can the minimal group paradigm be used to understand real-world conflicts? Options: A. By studying the impact of cultural differences on group behavior, B. By examining the role of social learning theory in shaping behavior, C. By analyzing the complex dynamics of group behavior and conflict, D. By applying the findings to resolve conflicts in real-world contexts Correct Option: C
Question 15: What is the significance of the minimal group paradigm in understanding human behavior? Options: A. It highlights the importance of cultural differences in shaping behavior, B. It demonstrates the impact of social learning theory on behavior, C. It shows how arbitrary group membership can lead to in-group bias, D. It provides insights into the complex dynamics of group behavior and conflict Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

However, an even more similar question is Question 8: What does the minimal group paradigm highlight about the nature of group membership?

Question 4 has the correct question intent but is missing the subject "Henri Tajfel and colleagues" in the question.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
In the years before World War Two, a pair of brothers worked together
as shoemakers in the German town of Herzogenaurach. But during the war, the siblings
had a terrible argument— a fight so explosive it split
the family business in two. At first, the feud only infected 
their newly competing personnel. But over the coming years, this disagreement divided
all of Herzogenaurach. Residents became fiercely
loyal to one brand of shoe. Local businesses chose sides and 
marriage across lines was discouraged. Herzogenaurach eventually became 
known as “the town of bent necks” because its residents looked down 
to ensure they were interacting with members of their group. But could such a serious divide
really be about shoes? Doesn’t it take more significant 
cultural differences to produce this degree of conflict? To answer this question, we can turn 
to social psychologist Henri Tajfel and his collaborators 
at the University of Bristol. This team developed 
the minimal group paradigm, a methodology designed to investigate the minimal conditions required 
to turn people against each other. Their plan was to gather participants 
without the usual factors that lead to hostility, such as religious, ethnic,

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The researchers working on the minimal group study purposefully used deception in order to:
Options: A. Confuse participants, B. Reduce bias and isolate the effects of group identity, C. Keep participants interested, D. Impair participants' decision-making abilities
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the years before World War Two, a pair of brothers worked together
as shoemakers in the German town of Herzogenaurach. But during the war, the siblings
had a terrible argument— a fight so explosive it split
the family business in two. At first, the feud only infected 
their newly competing personnel. But over the coming years, this disagreement divided
all of Herzogenaurach. Residents became fiercely
loyal to one brand of shoe. Local businesses chose sides and 
marriage across lines was discouraged. Herzogenaurach eventually became 
known as “the town of bent necks” because its residents looked down 
to ensure they were interacting with members of their group. But could such a serious divide
really be about shoes? Doesn’t it take more significant 
cultural differences to produce this degree of conflict? To answer this question, we can turn 
to social psychologist Henri Tajfel and his collaborators 
at the University of Bristol. This team developed 
the minimal group paradigm, a methodology designed to investigate the minimal conditions required 
to turn people against each other. Their plan was to gather participants 
without the usual factors that lead to hostility, such as religious, ethnic, 
gender, or other cultural differences. Then, they would split into groups, and run them through scenarios
that added one variable at a time to see what stirred up conflict. But first, they needed
a control condition— a pair of groups without any group bias. The researchers told participants
they were being grouped based on their ability to estimate things
correctly or incorrectly; but in reality, 
the groups were totally random. Since the researchers ensured none
of the participants interacted, no one could form any judgments
or personal bonds. Then everyone was given resources
to distribute. Each participant was free to give
resources to members of either group, and importantly, everything was anonymous. So whatever a participant decided, it had no impact on how many resources
they personally would receive. With all the ingredients 
for discrimination removed and no reason for competition
over resources, the scientists assumed this would
make a conflict-free baseline for further research. But even in these groups, where membership was only defined 
by a perceived similarity in possessing an arbitrary skill, individuals still showed in-group bias. They consistently gave more to members
of their own group than the out-group. Later, research went even further, informing participants that the only thing
determining their group membership was a coin flip. But group bias still occurred. The minimal groups of “us” and “them”
were enough. So, in the absence of stereotypes, 
resource conflicts and status differences, what was left? What could possibly account for people 
showing clear preferences for the most temporary and meaningless
of groups? The answer that came to Tajfel 
and his colleagues was social identity. People regularly use group membership 
to help determine their sense of identity. And these minimal group experiments
suggested that simply being categorized as part of a group is enough to link 
that group to a person’s sense of self. Then, in an effort to create
a meaningful identity, participants allocated more resources
to their in-group than the out-group— pursuing their group's interests despite
no clear benefit to themselves as individuals. Variants of these experiments have 
been conducted around the globe, examining how a shared sense 
of “us” can affect our attention, perception, memory, and emotions. The mental processes
behind minimal group distinctions appear to be the same as many of those
that underlie real group identities. So it is possible that these seemingly
insignificant differences can harden into much more serious divides. That said, minimal groups don't
always drive people apart. Bringing individuals together 
in a new group can temporarily help people
overcome entrenched biases. However, these positive effects are easily
negated by external factors that reinforce existing group identities. Ultimately, the psychology of groups
is part of the human condition, and our tendency towards in-group bias
is an undeniable part of that. So it's up to all of us to make
our groups and ourselves as inclusive of others as possible.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When allocating resources to other anonymous study participants, participants tended to favor:
Options: A. People who belonged to their same randomly assigned group, B. People who belonged to their same racial and ethnic group, C. People who they had met during their pre-interview, D. None of the above (people did not show bias towards any group or individual)
Correct Option: A
